DOC.HEAD: Leaflet Regulation Declared Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Monday declared unconstitutional a 1976 regulation barring people from passing out leaflets in an area around the White House. U.S. District Court Judge John Pratt issued the ruling in the case of a Carol Ann Fennelly, charged with illegally distributing pamphlets June 21 along East Executive Avenue between the White House and Treasury Department. The material urged passers-by to write members of Congress in favor of housing for the homeless. The judge said the regulation is an unconstitutional limitation on First Amendment rights. National Park Service regulations approved in 1970 were part of an effort to protect White House security by restrictions on demonstrations. The 1976 amendments were drafted to preserve an atmosphere of calm and tranquility at memorials and buildings associated with past presidents. In 1976, ``nothing was said about the underlying purpose of presidential security which was the overriding purpose of the comprehensive regulations issued in 1970,'' Pratt said. The 1970 regulation allowed distribution of pamphlets and leaflets by not mentioning them. ``In contrast, the 1976 revision ... for the first time banned'' distribution of material in the White House Park area, the judge said. Pratt noted that Fennelly ``would violate the regulation by passing out a leaflet,'' but ``could convey the same identical message by word of mouth without fear of arrest.'' ``A ban on the free distribution of leaflets and pamphlets in those remote areas far removed from the White House itself has no conceivable governmental interest,'' Pratt said in his opinion. ``It's distressing that the government continues to try to impose these ridiculous limitations on free speech in the nation's capital,'' said American Civil Liberties Union lawyer Arthur Spitzer, who handled the case.
